*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: Defendant has consistently failed to exercise joint legal decision‑making in good faith as contemplated by G.L. c. 208, § 31 and Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), which recognize that joint legal custody requires an ability and willingness to communicate and cooperate regarding major decisions affecting children.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses and defines joint legal custody under G.L. c. 208, § 31, but it does not address any requirement of an “ability and willingness to communicate and cooperate” between parents, nor does it analyze failures to exercise joint legal decision‑making in good faith. Its focus is on physical custody and removal, not on breakdowns of joint legal custody or communication between parents. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “The judge did award joint or shared legal custody, which G. L. c. 208, § 31 (1984 ed.), defines as ‘a continued mutual responsibility and involvement by both parents in decisions regarding the child’s welfare in matters of education, medical care, emotional, moral and religious development.’ As we have said, he awarded physical custody, or possession of the children, to the wife.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Defendant has consistently failed to exercise joint legal decision‑making in good faith as contemplated by G.L. c. 208, § 31 and Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), which recognize that joint legal custody requires an ability and willingness to communicate and cooperate regarding major decisions affecting children.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly defines shared legal custody under G.L. c. 208, § 31 as involving mutual responsibility for major decisions and then explains that joint custody is appropriate only where parents demonstrate an ability and desire to cooperate and communicate. It quotes Rolde for the proposition that joint custody is synonymous with joint decision-making and requires a willingness and ability to work together on major decisions. This directly supports citing Mason for the principle that joint legal custody requires an ability and willingness to communicate and cooperate regarding major decisions affecting children.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “Shared legal custody carries ‘mutual responsibility and involvement by both parents in major decisions regarding the child’s welfare including matters of education, medical care and emotional, moral and religious development.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31.… Although the General Laws state that there is no presumption ‘either in favor or against shared…custody,’… such an arrangement is generally appropriate only if the parties demonstrate an ability and desire to cooperate amicably and communicate with one another to raise the children.… ‘Joint custody is synonymous with joint decision making… [and] requires… a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions….’”}

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: Massachusetts law requires that custody and parenting-time orders be based on the best interests of the child. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); G.L. c. 208, § 31.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion does not restate the general ‘best interests of the child’ standard in so many words, but it clearly applies that framework: it focuses on how domestic violence and shared custody affect the child and remands for further findings because those impacts on the child were not adequately considered. The discussion of G.L. c. 208, § 31 and the requirement of written findings in light of domestic violence presupposes that custody and parenting arrangements must be evaluated in terms of their effect on the child’s welfare, i.e., the child’s best interests.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt:
“Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.

The Legislature reached a similar conclusion in respect to shared legal or physical custody. General Laws c. 208, § 31, provides that ‘[i]f, despite the prior or current issuance of a restraining order … the court shall provide written findings to support such shared custody order.’”}

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: A material and substantial change in circumstances affecting a child’s welfare warrants modification of an existing custody order. See *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981); *Heistand v. Heistand*, 384 Mass. 20 (1981); *Cooper v. Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 130 (2004).
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: Schuler addresses modification of alimony and child support based on a material change in the payor’s financial circumstances, not modification of a custody order or changes affecting a child’s welfare in the custody context. The opinion repeatedly states the standard as a “material change of circumstances” for alimony/support (citing Robbins and Hinds) and interprets G. L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 37, but it does not discuss modification of custody or analyze changes in circumstances specifically as to the child’s welfare for custody purposes. Thus it does not support the specific custody-related proposition for which it is cited.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28… A substantial and permanent decrease in the income of the support provider is one of the material circumstances to be considered…”}

*Heistand v. Heistand*, 384 Mass. 20 (19.proposition: A material and substantial change in circumstances affecting a child’s welfare warrants modification of an existing custody order. See *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981); *Heistand v. Heistand*, 384 Mass. 20 (1981); *Cooper v. Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 130 (2004).
*Heistand v. Heistand*, 384 Mass. 20 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the standard for modifying a child support order and cites Schuler v. Schuler for the governing principles. It states that modification is conditioned on a demonstrated change in circumstances and that the extent and palpability of such change is within the judge’s discretion, then upholds an upward modification based on the father’s increased salary. Although the case deals with support rather than custody, it clearly affirms the general rule that a material change in circumstances affecting the child’s needs and the payor’s ability warrants modification of an existing order.
*Heistand v. Heistand*, 384 Mass. 20 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant urges that the judgment requiring him to pay $20 more per child each week was unsupported by evidence of a material change in circumstances. In the interests of finality this court has conditioned modification upon a demonstrated change in circumstances after entry of the original decree. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961)… Unless the judge’s order is totally without basis in the record we give deference to her firsthand evaluation… See Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 370 (1981)… The judge exercised appropriate discretion in evaluating the totality of the factual circumstances.”

*Cooper v. Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 13.proposition: A material and substantial change in circumstances affecting a child’s welfare warrants modification of an existing custody order. See *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981); *Heistand v. Heistand*, 384 Mass. 20 (1981); *Cooper v. Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 130 (2004).
*Cooper v. Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 13.support_reasoning: The opinion is a modification case, but it concerns modification of child support and alimony, not custody. The court repeatedly frames the standard as a “material change in circumstances” regarding support obligations (income changes, needs, lifestyle), with no discussion of custody or a requirement that the change be “substantial” and affect the child’s welfare in the custody sense. Thus, Cooper v. Cooper does not provide authority for the specific custody-focused proposition stated.
*Cooper v. Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 13.relevant_excerpt:
“In this appeal from a judgment of modification, Philip Cooper also challenges the increased alimony award, claiming that Peggy Cooper, his former wife, failed to establish a material change in circumstances justifying increases in alimony and child support…

…‘where the trial court has previously passed on the issue of alimony in the divorce judgment, the correct course of action … is the post-divorce complaint for modification, implicating the traditional test of a material change in circumstances.’ Buckley v. Buckley, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 716, 719 (1997).”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Under *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), and *Custody of Roche*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 806 (1987), the Court evaluates whether a proposed modification is in the child’s best interests in light of current conditions, even where an existing order has been functioning, if the new circumstances show a detrimental impact on the child’s welfare.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the standard for modification of an existing custody order based on new, detrimental circumstances. Custody of Kali expressly refuses to treat the case as a modification proceeding and declines to apply the “substantial change in circumstances” standard, analyzing the matter instead as an initial custody determination under the best-interests standard of G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a). While Kali discusses best interests and stability, it does not hold that, in a modification posture, courts evaluate proposed changes in light of current conditions and detrimental impact on the child; indeed, it treats that modification framework as waived.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”

*Custody of Roche*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 80.proposition: Under *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), and *Custody of Roche*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 806 (1987), the Court evaluates whether a proposed modification is in the child’s best interests in light of current conditions, even where an existing order has been functioning, if the new circumstances show a detrimental impact on the child’s welfare.

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: Joint legal custody is appropriate only where the parents can communicate and cooperate in advancing the child’s best interests. See *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. at 184.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses when joint custody is appropriate and expressly conditions its appropriateness on the parents’ ability to agree on basic child-rearing issues and to cooperate. The court endorses the trial judge’s view that joint custody requires mutual agreement, willingness, and ability to work together in advancing the children’s best interests, and it rejects joint custody here precisely because the parents could not communicate and cooperate. This aligns with the claimed proposition.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually ‘to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.’ … Joint custody is synonymous with joint decision making and a common desire to promote the children’s best interests. … [I]n order to be effective ‘joint custody requires two capable parents with some degree of respect for one another’s abilities as parents, together with a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions….’”

*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610,.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that a parent’s willingness and ability to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent is a critical factor in determining custody. See *Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610, 619–20 (1986); *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225–27 (1998).
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610,.support_reasoning: The opinion is a care-and-protection case about parental unfitness versus State custody, not a dispute between two parents over who should have custody. The court discusses standards of proof, parental fitness, and children’s need for a safe, stable environment, but it does not address or weigh a parent’s willingness or ability to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent as a custody factor. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition cited.
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610,.relevant_excerpt: “In custody proceedings, the rights of the children to a stable and safe environment assume an importance at least equal to the interest of the parents in a fair proceeding. … The judge could properly have concluded that committing the children to the custody of the department would be in their best interest.”

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that a parent’s willingness and ability to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent is a critical factor in determining custody. See *Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610, 619–20 (1986); *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225–27 (1998).
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u.support_reasoning: The opinion is an adoption/placement decision between a foster mother and an aunt after parental rights have been terminated; it does not involve competing claims of two legal parents or discuss a custodian’s willingness or ability to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent. The court’s best‑interests analysis focuses on developmental needs, stability, attachments, and relative/foster placements, not on promoting a child’s relationship with an opposing parent. Thus, it does not establish the principle that fostering the child’s relationship with the other parent is a critical custody factor.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u.relevant_excerpt: Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The “best interests of a child” is a question that presents the trial judge “with a classic example of a discretionary decision.” ... Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.
